column1: By Fiona Ortiz
| CHICAGO
CHICAGO A prominent Illinois Republican has resigned from the state legislature
column2: citing multiple incidents of fake Facebook and Twitter accounts set up in his name in recent weeks. ""After some cyber security issues arose
column3: I began to re-evaluate my continued public service
column4: Representative Ron Sandack
column5: House Republican floor leader
column6: said in a resignation letter dated Sunday and provided on Monday by the Republican Caucus.Sandack
column7: known as an adamant defender of Republican Governor Bruce Rauner's initiatives on the floor of the Democratic-dominated House
column8: was up for re-election in November against Democrat Greg Hose.His resignation comes as both major U.S. political parties are increasingly bedeviled by hacking
column9: including Friday's leak of emails that have embarrassed Democrats as they gather for the party's convention in Philadelphia this week.

column1: Sandack had been battling since July 4 to remove multiple fake Facebook and Twitter accounts in his name
column2: he told Capitol Fax
column3: a respected political blog based in Springfield
column4: the state capital.It is not clear what
column5: if anything
column6: the fake accounts posted in his name.

column1: Sandack
column2: who was an active user of social media
column3: has shut down his Facebook and Twitter accounts and has filed a police report regarding the fake ones
column4: Capitol Fax reported.A spokeswoman for Jim Durkin
column5: leader of the House Republicans
column6: did not respond to a question on who would replace Sandack as Republican candidate for his seat. Rauner did not respond to reporters' questions about Sandack following an event on Monday morning.

column1: Sandack is a Chicago lawyer and former mayor of Downers Grove
column2: Illinois. He was appointed in 2010 to the Illinois Senate to fill in for a senator who resigned
column3: and went on to be elected as representative for his suburban Chicago district.In his resignation notice he also said he was no longer willing to miss so many family events. (Editing by Matthew Lewis)"	['Rauner']	[]

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-russia-fbi-idUSKCN1051TD	Democratic Party email leak points to Russia: cyber experts
column2: U.S. officials	"

column1: By Dustin Volz and Mark Hosenball
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Cyber security experts and U.S. officials said on Monday there was evidence that Russia engineered the release of sensitive Democratic Party emails in order to influence the U.S. presidential election.The FBI said it was investigating a cyber intrusion at the Democratic National Committee (DNC)
column2: which has led to discord as  the party's convention in Philadelphia opens on Monday to nominate former U.S. secretary of state Hillary Clinton as its candidate.Although the hacking of the DNC was known to officials and cyber security experts a month ago
column3: the timing of the release of the contents of communications within the party is what is causing concern for U.S. authorities.A U.S. official involved in the investigation said that the classified information collected on the hack so far ""indicated beyond a reasonable doubt that it originated in Russia."" The official
column4: speaking on condition of anonymity
column5: said that the timing of the release of emails ""has all the hallmarks of a classic intelligence operation intended to damage a perceived adversary.""The official said
column6: however
column7: that it may be impossible to prove definitively that Russian President Vladimir Putin's government directed the attack.The emails
column8: released by activist group WikiLeaks at the weekend
column9: appeared to show favoritism within the DNC for Clinton over U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont
column10: who ran a close race for the nomination for the Nov. 8 election. The committee is supposed to be neutral and the disclosure forced chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz
column12: to resign.The U.S. House of Representatives intelligence committee has been briefed and will seek information on any potential connection to Russia or any other state
column14: the senior Democrat on the panel.

column1: That foreign actors may be trying to influence our election - let alone a powerful adversary like Russia - should concern all Americans of any party."" Schiff said in a statement.On Sunday
column2: Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook told CNN that the campaign had been told by ""experts"" that the emails were released by suspected Russian hackers to help Republican Party nominee Donald Trump.The businessman's campaign dismissed the allegation as absurd.Trump has often praised Putin
column3: calling him a ""strong leader."" Trump is a critic of NATO and last week he  told The New York Times that he might not back countries in the alliance if they were attacked by Russia
column4: unless he was sure they had made sufficient contributions to the group.

column1: Russia has long been considered among the most elite U.S. adversaries in cyberspace
column2: though its actions are generally viewed as efforts at covert intelligence gathering.""Usually
column3: the Russians are not ham-handed
column4: said Jim Lewis
column5: a cyber security expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. He said Russia was believed to have hacked Democratic and Republican campaigns in 2008
column6: but that it did not leak material.""It would be a bold move to try and shape the election
column7: but we can't rule it out
column9: a cyber firm that helped clean up the breach
column10: said last month it had identified two hacking groups that infiltrated the DNC and that both were believed to be working on behalf of two competing arms of the Russian government.

column1: Its findings were later supported by similar conclusions reached by FireEye's (FEYE.O) Mandiant unit and Fidelis
column2: two other U.S.-based cyber companies.  Experts said that forensic analysis of the breach also links the same hackers to attacks at the White House
column3: the State Department
column4: the German Bundestag and private companies.The Federal Bureau of Investigation declined to say when its probe of the hack began. ""A compromise of this nature is something we take very seriously
column5: and the FBI will continue to investigate and hold accountable those who pose a threat in cyberspace
column6: it said in a statement.WikiLeaks released more than 19
column7: 000 DNC emails on Saturday. On Twitter it rejected as speculation claims made that Russia was the source of the cache. The group also said that there would be more leaks related to the U.S. election.White House spokesman Josh Earnest said he could not speak to the veracity of private sector conclusions pointing to Russia as the culprit in the DNC hack
column8: but that he was confident the FBI would thoroughly investigate the matter. (Reporting by Dustin Volz and Mark Hosenball; additional reporting by John Walcott and Joseph Menn; Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Grant McCool)"	['Schiff'

By Nate Raymond
A Florida man pleaded guilty on Monday to working with another man to illegally funnel $80
column2: 000 in foreign contributions to U.S. President Barack Obama's joint fundraising committee in 2012 so that a foreign national could attend a campaign event.William Argeros
column4: pleaded guilty in federal court in Newark
column5: New Jersey

column7: prosecutors said.U.S. law prohibits contributions from foreign nationals to candidates or fundraising committees in federal elections.A lawyer for Argeros did not respond to a request for comment. The Tampa
column9: resident is scheduled to be sentenced on Nov. 9.The proceedings came a month after an earlier guilty plea in the case by Bilal Shehu
column10: a New Jersey limousine driver to whom prosecutors said Argeros facilitated the transferring of $80

column1: Prosecutors said Shehu
column2: a Paramus
column3: New Jersey resident
column4: then provided the money to Obama's joint fundraising committee so that a foreign national could attend a campaign event on Oct. 8
column6: in San Francisco.In announcing both guilty pleas
column7: prosecutors have not specifically identified the foreign source of the money or the foreign national.

column1: But the cases came after a Republican congressman in 2013 called for investigations into the purchases by Shehu's family of two $40
column2: 000 tickets for a San Francisco fundraiser
column3: one of which was used by now-Albanian Prime Minister Edi Rama.At the October 2012 event
column4: Rama
column5: the Albanian Socialist Party leader
column6: was photographed with Obama.U.S. Representative Dana Rohrabacher of California at the time contended the photo was then used for ""deceitful"" purposes by Rama to imply a relationship with Obama during Albania's own election

column1: Prosecutors have said that the foreign national in the case was denied entry to the campaign event but was allowed to be photographed with Obama.Prosecutors said no one on the joint election committee has been accused of any wrongdoing and that it had cooperated fully in the investigation. (Reporting by Nate Raymond in New York; Editing by Bill Rigby)"	['Rohrabacher'

NAIROBI President Barack Obama's half-brother
column2: Malik Obama
column3: says he will vote for Republican nominee Donald Trump in the U.S. election in November because he likes the candidate and he is unhappy with his brother's leadership.Malik
column4: who is in his 50s

column1: The two men appear to have drifted apart but were previously close. column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-democrat-idUSKCN1040QN	Democratic Party head resigns amid email furor on eve of convention	"
By John Whitesides
| PHILADELPHIA
PHILADELPHIA The head of the Democratic Party resigned on Sunday amid a furor over embarrassing leaked emails
column2: hoping to head off a growing rebellion by Bernie Sanders supporters on the eve of the convention to nominate Hillary Clinton for the White House.Lingering bitterness from the heated primary campaign between Clinton and Sanders erupted after more than 19
column3: 000 Democratic National Committee emails
column4: leaked on Friday
column5: confirmed Sanders' frequent charge that the party played favorites in the race.In a statement
column6: DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz said the best way for the party to accomplish its goal of putting Clinton in the White House was for her to step aside after the convention. Sanders had demanded earlier in the day that Wasserman Schultz resign.The furor was a blow to a party keen on projecting stability in contrast to the volatility of Republican candidate Donald Trump
column7: who was formally nominated at a raucous convention in Cleveland last week.It also overshadowed preparations in Philadelphia for Clinton's coronation as the nominee to face Trump in the Nov. 8 presidential election. She will be the first woman nominated for president by a major U.S. political party. The four-day Democratic convention will open on Monday. In some good news for Clinton
column8: The New York Times reported that businessman and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg will endorse her in a prime-time speech on Monday
column9: saying she will be the best choice for moderate voters in 2016.The cache of emails leaked on Friday by the WikiLeaks website disclosed that DNC officials explored ways to undermine Sanders' insurgent presidential campaign
column10: including raising questions about whether Sanders
column12: was really an atheist.Sanders said Wasserman Schultz
column14: had made the right decision for the future of the Democratic Party. ""The party leadership must also always remain impartial in the presidential nominating process
column15: something which did not occur in the 2016 race

column4: that Bernie Sanders ... never had a chance

column10: an independent U.S. senator from Vermont who ran for president as a Democrat

column12: Sanders galvanized young and liberal voters with his calls to rein in Wall Street and eradicate income inequality.   But Sanders repeatedly voiced frustration with a DNC and party establishment he felt was stacked against him
column13: and the resentment from Sanders and his supporters threatened to disrupt the convention.

My Southern Baptist peeps would draw a big difference between a Jew and an atheist.""Clinton told CBS's ""60 Minutes"" in an interview that aired on Sunday that she had not read any of the emails but it was ""wrong and unacceptable"" to bring religion into the political process.

column1: SANDERS SUPPORTERS ANGRY
The emails angered many Sanders supporters who were already dismayed by Clinton's choice on Friday of low-key U.S. Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia as her vice presidential running mate. Kaine

column12: he said. Carrying pitchforks meant to portray Clinton as the devil

column15: that this was completely rigged right from the beginning
column16: and that you know it was really about what they were doing everything to set it up so she would win
